abstract: The government is funding research into techniques that may make caring for those with Alzheimer’s less burdensome.
snippet: The government is funding research into techniques that may make caring for those with Alzheimer’s less burdensome.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today on research into new ways to care for people with Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
headline.main: Caregiving and Dementia: New Ideas

abstract: South Korea struggles with rising numbers of citizens with Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: South Korea struggles with rising numbers of citizens with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning on efforts in South Korea, one of the fastest-aging nations, to grapple with an epidemic Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: A War on Dementia

abstract: A new word entered the Big Apple lexicon this week, and it’s not a happy one.
snippet: A new word entered the Big Apple lexicon this week, and it’s not a happy one.
lead_paragraph: This week has been an educational one in New York City.
headline.main: In a Word for Third, a Shovelful of Indignity

abstract: In his latest novel, Walter Mosley draws on lessons learned while coping with his mother’s dementia.
snippet: In his latest novel, Walter Mosley draws on lessons learned while coping with his mother’s dementia.
lead_paragraph: Ptolemy Usher Grey, who’s 91 and living in confused isolation in Los Angeles, keeps radio and television news blaring all day long, partly to keep himself from drifting ever farther into the past, partly because he’s afraid that if he turns them off, he won’t remember how to turn them back on.
headline.main: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: Memory’s Echo

abstract: South Korea is training thousands, including children, as “dementia supporters,” to recognize symptoms and care for patients.
snippet: South Korea is training thousands, including children, as “dementia supporters,” to recognize symptoms and care for patients.
lead_paragraph: SEONGNAM, South Korea  They were stooped, hobbled, disoriented, fumbling around the house. They got confused in the bathtub and struggled up stairs that seemed to swim before them.

abstract: Those middle-aged smokers who use two packs a day have twice the risk, according to a study of 23,123 health plan members.
snippet: Those middle-aged smokers who use two packs a day have twice the risk, according to a study of 23,123 health plan members.
lead_paragraph: Middle-aged smokers are far more likely than nonsmokers to develop dementia later in life, and heavy smokers  those who go through more than two packs a day  are at more than double the risk, a new study reports.
headline.main: Risks: Smokers Found More Prone to Dementia

lead_paragraph: We don’t watch sports because we think it is the very best use of the precious time we are granted in this life. The games entertain us. Distract us from our troubles. We like speed, violence, a hint of threat and danger because those elements raise the stakes and enhance the excitement.

snippet: Men develop mild cognitive impairment, often a precursor to Alzheimer’s disease, earlier and at higher rates than women, according to a new study.

abstract: Though recent evidence shows two types of tests can detect Alzheimer’s early, so far nothing has been found to prevent or delay the devastating disease.

lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md.  The scene was a kind of science court. On trial was the question “Can anything  running on a treadmill, eating more spinach, learning Arabic  prevent Alzheimer’s disease or delay its progression?”

abstract: Writers remember the people in their lives with Alzheimer’s, and the result is a potent, poignant book.
snippet: Writers remember the people in their lives with Alzheimer’s, and the result is a potent, poignant book.
lead_paragraph: Nearly nine years ago, the poet and essayist Holly J. Hughes’s 75-year-old mother died from Alzheimer’s disease. Her mother’s decline had been “a slow process of subtraction, as we lost her one brain cell, one synapse at a time,” Ms. Hughes writes in the preface to a new collection of poetry about this rampaging disease. “As with any grief that feels unspeakable, I turned to poetry.”
headline.main: Poets of Dementia

abstract: A new study finds that surprising numbers of older women with severe dementia are receiving routine mammograms.
snippet: A new study finds that surprising numbers of older women with severe dementia are receiving routine mammograms.
lead_paragraph: I’m trying, with some difficulty, to imagine myself as a woman in her 80s, someone with such advanced cognitive impairment that I can correctly answer fewer than a third of the questions on a commonly used test. I might not know who the president is, or what day or date it is; I might not be able to remember a few nouns the test giver just recited. Asked the question, “What is the object used to cut paper?” I might not be able to come up with the word scissors.
headline.main: Mammograms and Severe Dementia

abstract: A workers’ compensation claim on behalf of Ralph Wenzel, a lineman from 1966 to 1973, could be worth more than $1 million. Other players could file similar claims.
snippet: A workers’ compensation claim on behalf of Ralph Wenzel, a lineman from 1966 to 1973, could be worth more than $1 million. Other players could file similar claims.
lead_paragraph: VAN NUYS, Calif. — The five paper-clipped sheets that were slipped into a wire basket at the Van Nuys State Office Building looked no different from the other workers’ compensation claims filed by welders and cashiers. But this packet was different: it will almost certainly become a test case in considering National Football League teams’ liability for the dementia experienced by retired players.

abstract: Robert B. Schaefer, a retired F.B.I. agent, answers questions from readers about how to help dementia patients prone to wandering.
snippet: Robert B. Schaefer, a retired F.B.I. agent, answers questions from readers about how to help dementia patients prone to wandering.
lead_paragraph: The correspondent Kirk Johnson reports in Tuesday’s Times that frequent searches for people with dementia or Alzheimer’s disease are fueling a need to retrain emergency workers, police and volunteers around the country. They must throw out just about every generally accepted idea when hunting for people who are, in many ways, lost from the inside out.
headline.main: Readers’ Questions: Dementia and Wandering

abstract: A new study finds that aggressive treatment of pneumonia in severely demented patients did not improve the quality of their remaining months.
snippet: A new study finds that aggressive treatment of pneumonia in severely demented patients did not improve the quality of their remaining months.
lead_paragraph: The 323 residents living in Boston-area nursing homes had entered the final stages of dementia.
headline.main: When Pneumonia Follows Severe Dementia

abstract: Fifteen tips for elder-proofing a home for a parent with dementia.
snippet: Fifteen tips for elder-proofing a home for a parent with dementia.
lead_paragraph: Just about everyone with an older parent living alone worries about falls, and there is no shortage of suggestions for how to elder-proof a home in order to minimize trips and slips. But experts say it is also important to minimize household dangers for people with dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: Making Homes Safer for Dementia Patients

abstract: Sleep apnea can mimic or exacerbate symptoms of cognitive decline in the elderly.
snippet: Sleep apnea can mimic or exacerbate symptoms of cognitive decline in the elderly.
lead_paragraph: The woman who came to see Dr. Ronald Petersen, an Alzheimer’s specialist at the Mayo Clinic, was only in her 60s but complained that she was having trouble concentrating. “Her attention was waning,” Dr. Petersen recalled. “She couldn’t follow a television program or stay focused during a conversation.”
headline.main: When Sleep Apnea Masquerades as Dementia

abstract: Why aren’t terminal patients with advanced dementia being placed in hospice care?
snippet: Why aren’t terminal patients with advanced dementia being placed in hospice care?
lead_paragraph: It’s hard for physicians to determine with much precision how long anyone with a terminal disease can expect to live, but it’s particularly challenging when the disease is advanced dementia.
headline.main: End-of-Life Care for Patients With Advanced Dementia

abstract: Hospitals say many patients, particularly older ones, are experiencing inexplicable disorienting episodes.
snippet: Hospitals say many patients, particularly older ones, are experiencing inexplicable disorienting episodes.
lead_paragraph: No one who knows Justin Kaplan would ever have expected this. A Pulitzer Prize-winning historian with a razor intellect, Mr. Kaplan, 84, became profoundly delirious while hospitalized for pneumonia last year. For hours in the hospital, he said, he imagined despotic aliens, and he struck a nurse and threatened to kill his wife and daughter.

abstract: How putting in a pacemaker wrecked a family’s life.
snippet: How putting in a pacemaker wrecked a family’s life.
lead_paragraph: One October afternoon three years ago while I was visiting my parents, my mother made a request I dreaded and longed to fulfill. She had just poured me a cup of Earl Grey from her Japanese iron teapot, shaped like a little pumpkin; outside, two cardinals splashed in the birdbath in the weak Connecticut sunlight. Her white hair was gathered at the nape of her neck, and her voice was low. “Please help me get Jeff’s pacemaker turned off,” she said, using my father’s first name. I nodded, and my heart knocked.

abstract: A week after they were criticized for sounding like the old guard, the co-chairmen of the N.F.L.’s committee on brain injuries take a strong stand.
snippet: A week after they were criticized for sounding like the old guard, the co-chairmen of the N.F.L.’s committee on brain injuries take a strong stand.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  They accused a fellow doctor of minimizing solid evidence of the dangers of football concussions. They concurred that data collected by the N.F.L.’s former brain-injury leadership was “infected,” said that their committee should be assembled anew, and formally requested that the group’s former chairman, Dr. Elliot Pellman, not speak at a conference Wednesday.

snippet: Boston University’s School of Medicine’s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy has warned of the long-term effects of head trauma and been critical of the N.F.L.’s stance on concussions.

abstract: A study showed that people who mostly ate foods low in saturated fat and rich in nutrients were at one-third lower risk of the disease than those who ate more higher-fat foods.
snippet: A study showed that people who mostly ate foods low in saturated fat and rich in nutrients were at one-third lower risk of the disease than those who ate more higher-fat foods.
lead_paragraph: Older adults appear to be at lower risk for Alzheimer’s disease if they eat a diet rich in fish, poultry, fruit, nuts, dark leafy greens, vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower, and oil-and-vinegar dressing, a new study has found.
headline.main: Aging: Diet May Be Linked to Lower Alzheimer’s Risk in Older People
headline.print_headline: AGING: Diet Is Linked to a Lower Alzheimer’s Risk

abstract: A new study found that older people hospitalized for a critical condition had a statistically significant drop in scores on cognitive tests when compared with people who had not been hospitalized.
snippet: A new study found that older people hospitalized for a critical condition had a statistically significant drop in scores on cognitive tests when compared with people who had not been hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: Older people are more likely to suffer a decline in their cognitive abilities after being hospitalized for an illness than they would otherwise, a new study reports.
headline.main: Aging: Cognitive Decline and Hospitalization
headline.print_headline: AGING: Cognitive Decline and Hospitalization

abstract: Ron Mix and Mel Owens serve as workers’ compensation lawyers for hundreds of fellow retired N.F.L. players who have sold their rights to medical care for lump sums.
snippet: Ron Mix and Mel Owens serve as workers’ compensation lawyers for hundreds of fellow retired N.F.L. players who have sold their rights to medical care for lump sums.
lead_paragraph: As workers’ compensation lawyers go, Ron Mix and Mel Owens understand their clients’ problems better than most.

abstract: New guidelines on driving and dementia are less definitive than many caregivers might have hoped for.
snippet: New guidelines on driving and dementia are less definitive than many caregivers might have hoped for.
lead_paragraph: You might hope that when the American Academy of Neurology reviews and updates its decade-old guidelines on driving and dementia, the experts would come up with clear-cut recommendations: a specific score on a specific test means someone can head for the mall without much concern, or a  particular behavior means it’s too risky to be on the road, so hand over the keys.
headline.main: Driving While Demented

abstract: One of the first signs of impending dementia: an inability to understand money and contracts.
snippet: One of the first signs of impending dementia: an inability to understand money and contracts.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning on the difficult questions raised for lawyers, doctors and financial advisers when a client begins to show signs of dementia.
headline.main: Personal Finances and Alzheimer’s

snippet: Facing dementia, one woman celebrates her 75th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Facing dementia, one woman celebrates her 75th birthday.

snippet: Older people with the highest levels of “good” HDL cholesterol were 60 percent less likely to develop Alzheimer’s than those with the lowest HDL levels.
lead_paragraph: Could HDL cholesterol — the good kind linked to lower heart disease risk — also protect people from dementia?
headline.main: ‘Good’ Cholesterol May Lower Alzheimer’s Risk

abstract: Some residents of a Minnesota town argue that a proposed assisted living facility for dementia patients is a threat to children.
snippet: Some residents of a Minnesota town argue that a proposed assisted living facility for dementia patients is a threat to children.
lead_paragraph: So much for the stereotype of those nice, welcoming Minnesotans.
headline.main: A Danger to the Community?

abstract: A new guide to caring for those with Alzheimer’s does not shy away from difficult and sensitive issues.
snippet: A new guide to caring for those with Alzheimer’s does not shy away from difficult and sensitive issues.
lead_paragraph: The National Institute on Aging’s new guide for those caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease, which I recommended a few weeks ago, drew generally positive reviews from New Old Age readers.
headline.main: Answers for Tough Questions About Alzheimer’s

abstract: A Phoenix nursing home has found that unlimited chocolate, and other comforts, go a long way in reducing patients’ distress.
snippet: A Phoenix nursing home has found that unlimited chocolate, and other comforts, go a long way in reducing patients’ distress.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Margaret Nance was, to put it mildly, a difficult case. Agitated, combative, often reluctant to eat, she would hit staff members and fellow residents at nursing homes, several of which kicked her out. But when Beatitudes nursing home agreed to an urgent plea to accept her, all that changed.

abstract: A new study found that large hospitals and for-profit hospitals were more likely to use the tubes in caring for nursing home residents with advanced dementia.
snippet: A new study found that large hospitals and for-profit hospitals were more likely to use the tubes in caring for nursing home residents with advanced dementia.
lead_paragraph: When nursing home residents with advanced dementia are sent to the hospital, many are given feeding tubes, even though the practice is not believed to help them live longer. Now a new study finds that it is much more prevalent at some hospitals than others.
headline.main: Aging: Hospital Type May Play Role in Decision on Feeding Tubes
headline.print_headline: Aging: Feeding Tube Use May Depend on Hospital

abstract: Another new study suggests that body fat is bad for the brain.
snippet: Another new study suggests that body fat is bad for the brain.
lead_paragraph: Being fat is bad for your brain.
headline.main: Brain Damage

abstract: Guns signify independence to many frail seniors, including those with dementia, and often caregivers struggle with decisions about when to remove weapons from the homes of loved ones.
snippet: Guns signify independence to many frail seniors, including those with dementia, and often caregivers struggle with decisions about when to remove weapons from the homes of loved ones.
lead_paragraph: She is a 90-year-old widow with mild Alzheimer’s disease, and her son is begging her, for safety’s sake, to give up something she considers essential to her independence and sense of control.
headline.main: Guns in Frail Hands

abstract: New data on the effects of concussions on football players should prompt a re-evaluation of everything about the game.
snippet: New data on the effects of concussions on football players should prompt a re-evaluation of everything about the game.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League seems finally to have emerged from its cocoon of denial about the devastating long-term effects of concussions on professional football players. In November, it announced that players with concussions could not return to the field without the blessing of an independent brain-injury expert. It has also agreed to support research by its most vocal critics.
headline.main: Dangerous Game
headline.print_headline: Dangerous Game

abstract: The league and the players union agreed to expand qualifications for the 88 Plan aiding former players with medical expenses.
snippet: The league and the players union agreed to expand qualifications for the 88 Plan aiding former players with medical expenses.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. and the players union announced Monday that they would expand qualifications for the 88 Plan, which since 2007 has assisted former players with medical expenses related to dementia, to include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease.
headline.main: N.F.L. Agrees to Help Ex-Players Who Have A.L.S.
headline.print_headline: N.F.L. and Union to Help Former Players With A.L.S.

abstract: In “Happy Tears,” the writer and director Mitchell Lichtenstein struggles to find the humor in a host of horrors.
snippet: In “Happy Tears,” the writer and director Mitchell Lichtenstein struggles to find the humor in a host of horrors.
lead_paragraph: In “Happy Tears,” a comedy about the unhappy topic of family dysfunction, the writer and director Mitchell Lichtenstein (“Teeth”) struggles to find the humor in a host of horrors, including encroaching parental dementia. Unfortunately, to judge from the many awkwardly handled passages, Mr. Lichtenstein does not possess the requisite filmmaking skill or certainly the delicacy, to balance the different, often jarringly contrasting moods, jokes and intimate revelations squeezed into this erratic, belabored movie.

abstract: Experts predict a two- to threefold increase in the number of people with the disease if new guidelines are adopted, as expected.
snippet: Experts predict a two- to threefold increase in the number of people with the disease if new guidelines are adopted, as expected.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 25 years, medical experts are proposing a major change in the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier.
headline.main: Rules Seek to Expand Diagnosis of Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: GUIDELINES SEEK EARLY DETECTION OF ALZHEIMER’S

abstract: A expert at Duke has authored an unusually informative guide for caregivers and the elderly facing Alzheimer’s.
snippet: A expert at Duke has authored an unusually informative guide for caregivers and the elderly facing Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly 30 years since Dr. Peter Rabins, a Johns Hopkins psychiatrist, and his co-author Nancy Mace published “The 36-Hour Day,” the best known guide to caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease. Now in its fourth edition, it remains a trusted source of information and support.
headline.main: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: The Beginnings of Alzheimer’s

abstract: 313: The number of drugs — a record high — under research and development to treat mental illness.
snippet: 313: The number of drugs — a record high — under research and development to treat mental illness.
lead_paragraph: 313: The number of drugs — a record high — under research and development to treat mental illness, according to a new report by the Pharmaceutical Research and
headline.main: Prime Number
headline.print_headline: Prime Number

abstract: How far has a family member with Alzheimer’s declined? A new online tool tries to help users figure it out.
snippet: How far has a family member with Alzheimer’s declined? A new online tool tries to help users figure it out.
lead_paragraph: Many Web sites offer help for stressed caregivers in general and information on Alzheimer’s disease in particular (the Alzheimer’s Association site is particularly comprehensive). But they don’t fully harness the Web’s interactivity to provide specific, tailored advice regarding Alzheimer’s — recommendations that necessarily change as patients’ behaviors and symptoms shift.
headline.main: Plotting the Course of Alzheimer’s

abstract: Even in the later stages of dementia, many Alzheimer’s patients enjoy and benefit from books, experts have found.
snippet: Even in the later stages of dementia, many Alzheimer’s patients enjoy and benefit from books, experts have found.
lead_paragraph: Familiar music can engage those with Alzheimer’s when almost nothing else can, researchers have shown. Now it appears that books written for these patients may have a similar effect.
headline.main: Many Alzheimer’s Patients Find Comfort in Books

abstract: Researchers are trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate. If drugs can be given sooner, they say, treatment might be more successful.
snippet: Researchers are trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate. If drugs can be given sooner, they say, treatment might be more successful.
lead_paragraph: Much of the research on Alzheimer’s next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

snippet: Micky Ward, the real-life subject of the new David O. Russell movie “The Fighter,” has agreed to donate his organs after he dies to further the study of punch drunk syndrome.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to say whether such a move will curry favor with the Academy, but Micky Ward, the boxer at the center of the based-on-real-life story “The Fighter,” has pledged to help science by donating his brain for medical research.

abstract: An early sign of dementia is an inability to understand money, leaving financial advisers and lawyers in a bind.
snippet: An early sign of dementia is an inability to understand money, leaving financial advisers and lawyers in a bind.
lead_paragraph: Renee Packel used to have a typical suburban life. Her husband, Arthur, was a lawyer and also sold insurance. They lived in a town house just outside Philadelphia, and Mrs. Packel took care of their home and family.

abstract: Wednesday | Today’s idea: We’re becoming a “neurocapitalist” world, an essay says. The demands of performance-driven, self-enhancing societies will expand markets for neuro-psychotropic drugs beyond those for depression, dementia and attention deficit disorder. And they will cost our health care systems dearly. [Eurozine via Merkur]
snippet: Wednesday | Today’s idea: We’re becoming a “neurocapitalist” world, an essay says. The demands of performance-driven, self-enhancing societies will expand markets for neuro-psychotropic drugs beyond those for depression, dementia and attention def...
lead_paragraph: Today’s idea: We’re becoming a “neurocapitalist” world, an essay says. The demands of performance-driven, self-enhancing societies will expand markets for neuro-psychotropic drugs beyond those for depression, dementia and attention deficit disorder. And they will cost our health care systems dearly.
headline.main: The Dawn of ‘Neurocapitalism’

abstract: A typical day for Dr. Subha Airan-Javia, a 32-year-old hospitalist, who splits her time between clinical care and information technology.
snippet: A typical day for Dr. Subha Airan-Javia, a 32-year-old hospitalist, who splits her time between clinical care and information technology.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Subha Airan-Javia, a 32-year-old hospitalist, splits her time between clinical care and information technology designed to save money and increase efficiency. “I’d be bored doing the same thing every day,” she said.
headline.main: A Busy Schedule Is Never Boring
headline.print_headline: A Busy Schedule Is Never Boring

abstract: Doctors are exploring a new option in palliative care: comfort feeding only.
snippet: Doctors are exploring a new option in palliative care: comfort feeding only.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports today on a new option in palliative care called “comfort feeding only.”
headline.main: An Alternative to the Feeding Tube

abstract: Tuesday, there was a match between elder French and Russian chess players that was part of a study to see if engaging in rigorous mental activity can prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Tuesday, there was a match between elder French and Russian chess players that was part of a study to see if engaging in rigorous mental activity can prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Chess can be diverting, amusing, engrossing, perplexing, exasperating, infuriating, and a few other things. But is it good for your mental health?
headline.main: Can Playing Chess Prevent Alzheimer’s Disease?

abstract: Larry King on the question: What would it take to go?
snippet: Larry King on the question: What would it take to go?
lead_paragraph: Larry King ended his run as the 9 p.m. fixture on CNN last week. Between his radio career and his stint on television, he did about 50,000 interviews. When Jacques Steinberg of The Times visited him in Beverly Hills in 2007, he had recently undergone a procedure for a clogged artery.

snippet: Are psychoactive medications overused in nursing homes?
lead_paragraph: The number jumped out at me as I was reading a newly published study on mental health treatment in nursing homes: 71 percent.

lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson paid kickbacks to the nation’s largest nursing home pharmacy to increase the number of elderly patients taking the antipsychotic Risperdal and several other medications, according to a complaint filed Friday by the office of the United States attorney in Boston.

abstract: Researchers have tested the Sensecam, which contains a digital camera and an accelerometer, as an aid to people with Alzheimer’s disease and other memory disorders.
snippet: Researchers have tested the Sensecam, which contains a digital camera and an accelerometer, as an aid to people with Alzheimer’s disease and other memory disorders.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — On a cold, wet afternoon not long ago, Aron Reznick sat in the lounge of a home for the elderly here, his silver hair neatly combed, his memory a fog. He could not remember Thanksgiving dinner with his family, though when he was given a hint — “turkey” — it came back to him, vaguely, like a shadow in the moonlight.

abstract: Changes to the psychiatry guidebook that largely sets society’s line for normal behavior could affect treatment.
snippet: Changes to the psychiatry guidebook that largely sets society’s line for normal behavior could affect treatment.
lead_paragraph: Far fewer children would get a diagnosis of bipolar disorder. “Binge eating disorder” and “hypersexuality” might become part of the everyday language. And the way many mental disorders are diagnosed and treated would be sharply revised.

abstract: A look at the plight of a family struggling to protect a homestead secured with a type of home loan since outlawed in California.
snippet: A look at the plight of a family struggling to protect a homestead secured with a type of home loan since outlawed in California.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s Barbary Coast column is about a Redwood City family on the verge of losing its homestead. The property looks like a slice of Positano in Silicon Valley, peppered with three homes on a steep countryside hill. Eight people live on the grounds.
headline.main: A Family Property at Risk

abstract: For all the assertions about the importance of caring in medicine, doctors as a profession have been slow to recognize family members who care for patients at home, writes Dr. Pauline Chen.
snippet: For all the assertions about the importance of caring in medicine, doctors as a profession have been slow to recognize family members who care for patients at home, writes Dr. Pauline Chen.
lead_paragraph: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline W. Chen writes about an aging patient with early dementia. But it was the man’s middle-aged son who made the biggest impression. She writes:
headline.main: Who Takes Care of the Caregiver?

abstract: A record number of drugs are in research and development stages for conditions that the government says affect one in four Americans.
snippet: A record number of drugs are in research and development stages for conditions that the government says affect one in four Americans.
lead_paragraph: There are a record 313 drugs under research and development to treat mental illness, the pharmaceutical manufacturers’ association says in a new report.
headline.main: A Record Number of Drugs Are Being Tested to Treat Mental Illness

abstract: Mr. Massera had been in charge of a notorious political prison where thousands were tortured and killed.
snippet: Mr. Massera had been in charge of a notorious political prison where thousands were tortured and killed.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES  Emilio Massera, a leader of the military junta of Argentina’s bloody dictatorship and the former head of the country’s most notorious political prison, where an estimated 5,000 people were tortured and killed, died here on Monday. He was 85.

abstract: Caregiving families must adapt to the loss of cherished holiday rituals.
snippet: Caregiving families must adapt to the loss of cherished holiday rituals.
lead_paragraph: Mary Devitt’s family counted on certain traditions each Christmas. Her mother cooked the entire meal and served it on the good china, carefully arrayed on a tablecloth she’d appliqued with holly sprigs. The centerpiece was always the same, a Royal Doulton figurine of a little boy with a Christmas tree. Her father sliced the turkey, using the carving set reserved for special occasions.
headline.main: Changing the Family Traditions

abstract: A jazz singer grapples with her mother’s memory loss.
snippet: A jazz singer grapples with her mother’s memory loss.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Scott’s voice came wafting out of my car radio on a Sunday morning. She’s a lovely singer, a veteran of jazz clubs and international festivals and, back when, one of Ray Charles’s Raelettes.
headline.main: A Song About Forgetting

abstract: In “Lil’s 90th,” at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, a look at how dementia can devastate even the most loving family.
snippet: In “Lil’s 90th,” at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, a look at how dementia can devastate even the most loving family.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, love is not all you need. In fact, it can be downright dangerous. Love abounds in the family depicted in Darci Picoult’s new play, “Lil’s 90th”; but the Eldridges are in big, big trouble anyway.

abstract: A damaged former football pro befriends a high school quarterback in this novel.
snippet: A damaged former football pro befriends a high school quarterback in this novel.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Popovich is a former linebacker for two National Football League teams who still loves to hit, even at age 54. He craves the “pop,” the sound of brutal, body-on-body, bone-jangling contact. But that alone does not make him a memorable character. Charlie, who is immensely likable, has Alzheimer’s disease, the central fact of “Pop.”
headline.main: Game Face
headline.print_headline: Game Face

abstract: How to find appropriate activities for a memory-impaired parent.
snippet: How to find appropriate activities for a memory-impaired parent.
lead_paragraph: I’ve invited the clinical psychologist Cynthia Green, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and the author of several books on memory (including “Through the Seasons: An Activities Book for Memory Challenged Adults and Caregivers“), to join the conversation today. I’ve been hearing laments about the difficulties of visiting relatives with dementia; people yearn to make that time together enjoyable and meaningful, but they can’t always figure out how to connect. Dr. Green has some thoughtful suggestions.
headline.main: Finding Activities for Parents With Memory Loss

lead_paragraph: Cliff Livingston, who played in four National Football League championship games as a linebacker for the Giants in the 1950s and 1960s, died March 13 at his home in Las Vegas. He was 79.

abstract: More medical research is needed to defeat Alzheimer’s disease before it’s too late to help the baby boom generation.
snippet: More medical research is needed to defeat Alzheimer’s disease before it’s too late to help the baby boom generation.
lead_paragraph: OUR government is ignoring what is likely to become the single greatest threat to the health of Americans: Alzheimer’s disease, an illness that is 100 percent incurable and 100 percent fatal. It attacks rich and poor, white-collar and blue, and women and men, without regard to party. A degenerative disease, it steadily robs its victims of memory, judgment and dignity, leaves them unable to care for themselves and destroys their brain and their identity — often depleting their caregivers and families both emotionally and financially.

abstract: This old football mentality of playing through pain is life-threatening, particularly in the murky area of brain injury.
snippet: This old football mentality of playing through pain is life-threatening, particularly in the murky area of brain injury.
lead_paragraph: The old football mentality  play through pain or get out of the way  can be dangerous, particularly in the murky area of brain injury.

abstract: The N.F.L. will donate $1 million without restrictions to a Boston University research center studying brain injuries.
snippet: The N.F.L. will donate $1 million without restrictions to a Boston University research center studying brain injuries.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at the Boston University School of Medicine’s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy have decided that the National Football League’s offer of support is what they had hoped: $1 million and zero strings.
headline.main: N.F.L. Donates $1 Million for Brain Studies

abstract: Lawmakers need to look at what is happening beyond the Beltway. While they refuse to provide more fiscal aid to states, their constituents are suffering.
snippet: Lawmakers need to look at what is happening beyond the Beltway. While they refuse to provide more fiscal aid to states, their constituents are suffering.
lead_paragraph: How bad does it have to get before Congress notices? Kevin Sack reported in The Times on Thursday that budget shortfalls have led 11 states to close enrollment in programs that provide drugs to people with H.I.V. and AIDS. Worse, the number of those turned away is expected to surge in the months ahead as more states defer enrollment and cut eligibility.

abstract: The league will assist a program that helps retired players apply for and receive disability and pension benefits.
snippet: The league will assist a program that helps retired players apply for and receive disability and pension benefits.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly one year since Gay Culverhouse sat before a Congressional committee and blistered the N.F.L.’s treatment of its retired players, the league announced Tuesday that it would support her Players’ Outreach Program to help identify and assist former players in need.

headline.print_headline: N.F.L. Backs Program for Ex-Players in Need

abstract: A Washington Post columnist and editorial writer who specialized in foreign affairs
snippet: A Washington Post columnist and editorial writer who specialized in foreign affairs
lead_paragraph: Stephen S. Rosenfeld, a retired columnist and editorial page editor of The Washington Post who wrote for many years on foreign affairs, died on Sunday in Springfield, Va. He was 77 and lived in Alexandria, Va.
headline.main: Stephen Rosenfeld, Retired Columnist, Dies at 77

abstract: The high school kids in “The Trotsky” are more interested in social activism than in sex.
snippet: The high school kids in “The Trotsky” are more interested in social activism than in sex.
lead_paragraph: The typical American high school comedy is more concerned with sex than with socialism, but leave it to Canada to reverse that balance. In “The Trotsky,” a study of teenage dementia set in Montreal, a privileged 17-year-old named Leon Bronstein (Jay Baruchel) is convinced he’s the reincarnation of Leon Trotsky.

abstract: This novel turns a teen’s fatal condition into a hilarious and hallucinatory quest.
snippet: This novel turns a teen’s fatal condition into a hilarious and hallucinatory quest.
lead_paragraph: You could say that this year’s winner of the Michael L. Printz Award for young adult literature, announced last month by the American Library Association, begins with an off-putting premise. The narrator, Cameron, a self-­proclaimed slacker (“I’m a drifter — right downstream and over the falls with the rest of the driftwood”), learns that he has contracted a fatal condition: Creutzfeldt-­Jakob, or mad cow, disease (as it’s known in animals). Who wants to read a 480-page novel about a 16-year-old who has four to six months to live and suffers from progressive muscle weakness, dementia and delusions?
headline.main: Morbidity and Hilarity
headline.print_headline: Morbidity and Hilarity

abstract: Though the goal is to live long and live well, only a minority of Americans incorporate into their lives what will give them the biggest bang for their buck: diet and exercise.
snippet: Though the goal is to live long and live well, only a minority of Americans incorporate into their lives what will give them the biggest bang for their buck: diet and exercise.
lead_paragraph: The Great Recession, so I’m told, has been great for one segment of the economy  the makers of pills and potions that offer the promise of keeping people healthy. A middle-aged woman remarked as she perused the supplement shelves in my local health food store (I was buying bulgur): “I can’t afford to get sick. I lost my job and I have no health insurance.”

abstract:
Sonoma County’s separation of two elderly gay partners,
Harold Scull and Clay M. Greene, and its sale of their belongings has drawn attention from around the Bay Area.
snippet:
Sonoma County’s separation of two elderly gay partners,
Harold Scull and Clay M. Greene, and its sale of their belongings has drawn attention from around the Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: Sonoma County’s separation of two elderly gay partners, Harold Scull and Clay M. Greene, and its sale of their belongings has drawn attention from around the Bay Area. Last month, a legal complaint was filed by Mr. Greene, the survivor of the couple. It alleges callous and unlawful behavior on the part of the officials who separated the men — Mr. Greene, 78, and Mr. Scull, who was 89 when he died nearly two years ago. It accuses the county and its employees of elder abuse and fraud.
headline.main: For Better, for Worse
headline.print_headline: For Better, For Worse

abstract: PBS  offers a clear-eyed look at dying patients and the end-of-life issues caregivers face in a new documentary, “Facing Death.”
snippet: PBS  offers a clear-eyed look at dying patients and the end-of-life issues caregivers face in a new documentary, “Facing Death.”
lead_paragraph: I’d be glad if a zillion people tuned in to watch “Facing Death,” an hour-long “Frontline” documentary airing on PBS Tuesday (at 9 or 10 p.m. in most places — check your local listings, or watch it online). I know that won’t happen; so many people still turn away from the subject. But half a zillion would be good, too.

abstract: Lack of sleep can lead to many medical problems and in rare cases may even prove fatal.
snippet: Lack of sleep can lead to many medical problems and in rare cases may even prove fatal.
lead_paragraph: Lack of sleep can make getting through the day a challenge and is increasingly tied to a host of medical problems. But can insomnia actually prove fatal? That was among the hundreds of questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog at “Ask an Expert: Overcoming Insomnia.”
headline.main: Can You Die of Insomnia?

abstract: The show, back on NBC for its fourth season, is melodrama that steers clear of feeling melodramatic.
snippet: The show, back on NBC for its fourth season, is melodrama that steers clear of feeling melodramatic.
lead_paragraph: Does it seem like overstating things to say that “Friday Night Lights’’ is the greatest television soap opera of all time? The series, which returned to NBC Friday night for its fourth season after an earlier run on DirecTV, whispers its heartaches and longings; it is melodrama that always manages to steer clear of feeling melodramatic. Often the show seems like a lesson in resilience to those members of its audience who are Eastern and privileged and lap it up. The people who live in the series’ fictional town of Dillon, Texas, never seem undone by the swelter of deprivation; they just go about the business of getting by.
headline.main: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Soap Opera for the Ages

abstract: The former co-chairman of the N.F.L.’s committee on brain injuries told a Congressional panel Monday that there is not enough evidence linking head injuries in football to brain damage.

abstract: How adult children can talk about money with their Depression-era parents, who are often reluctant to discuss the topic.
snippet: How adult children can talk about money with their Depression-era parents, who are often reluctant to discuss the topic.

abstract: Andrea Gillies’s caregiving memoir arrives in the United States trailing awards and awed reviews.
snippet: Andrea Gillies’s caregiving memoir arrives in the United States trailing awards and awed reviews.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Gillies’s memoir, “Keeper,” published in Britain last year, arrives here trailing awards and awed reviews, and I can see why. Though I wasn’t looking forward to still another account of life with deepening dementia, I read this one in a day.

abstract: A new book tells the story of a family coming to terms with assisted suicide.
snippet: A new book tells the story of a family coming to terms with assisted suicide.
lead_paragraph: I was talking to a woman in Rhode Island the other day whose father is in a nursing home with advanced dementia. Her weary mother had voiced a fairly common sentiment: “When I reach that point, just leave a bottle of pills by the bed.”
headline.main: A Mother’s Decision to Die

abstract: Steven M. Volpe, a recent college graduate and an avid computer user, turned his interest in social media into a job for the Alzheimer’s Association.
snippet: Steven M. Volpe, a recent college graduate and an avid computer user, turned his interest in social media into a job for the Alzheimer’s Association.
lead_paragraph: Steven M. Volpe, 21, who graduated in June from the College of Staten Island, parlayed an unpaid spring internship at the New York City chapter of the Alzheimer’s Association into a paid summer internship. In August he was offered a job as a social media associate. He lives with his parents in Dongan Hills on Staten Island and moonlights Saturday nights selling business machines at a local Staples.

abstract: Can the sheer volume of an elder’s possessions prevent him from making necessary transitions?

lead_paragraph: David J. Ekerdt, who directs the gerontology center at the University of Kansas, has a knack for digging into aspects of aging that most of us register only in passing. I’ve been a fan since I read his work on the “busy ethic,” a phrase he coined to describe our attitudes towards retirement.
headline.main: When Possessions Lead to Paralysis

abstract: Children are recorded on video almost from birth. Why aren’t the cameras trained on aging family members?
snippet: Children are recorded on video almost from birth. Why aren’t the cameras trained on aging family members?
lead_paragraph: Sally Mehl’s 75th birthday celebration was shaping up to be a major bash. All five children and six grandchildren would come to the small house in Roseland, N.J., where they’d grown up; the siblings were already parceling out responsibility for the food and the cake. Her daughter Ann would take Mrs. Mehl to the beauty shop for a wash-and-set. Even her cockapoo, Sarah, would be groomed in honor of the occasion.
headline.main: Remembering the Last Act

abstract: A sampling of news of interest to readers in the San Francisco Bay Area.
snippet: A sampling of news of interest to readers in the San Francisco Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: Prepared for the Big One? Not Exactly | As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sunday’s earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster. The budget challenges faced by firefighters and other first responders have probably affected preparedness, fire officials say, particularly in remote or lightly populated areas that often depend on larger cities or agencies for help in emergencies. Sunday’s quake registered 7.2 and centered in a largely unpopulated area of northern Mexico. But a recent study by the California Emergency Management Agency found a majority of the state’s households failing to meet recommendations for many basic emergency needs, like stockpiling water (a minimum of three gallons per person), reinforcing their homes and making disaster plans. “We know that there’s going to be an earthquake, and we know it’s going to be a major natural disaster,” said Lou Paulson, president of the California Professional Firefighters and a captain in the Contra Costa County fire protection district. “And I don’t want to be one of the people who stands in front of the state of California and says, ‘We told you so.’ ” [The New York Times]
headline.main: Sampler: Lack of Attention for Earthquake Preparations, and More Attention for ‘Story of Stuff ‘

abstract: A Swedish researcher explores ‘gerotranscendence’ and tackles the American ‘busy ethic.’
snippet: A Swedish researcher explores ‘gerotranscendence’ and tackles the American ‘busy ethic.’
lead_paragraph: When I asked Lars Tornstam, a Swedish sociologist, for an example of the state he calls gerotranscendence, he described a hypothetical daughter planning a cocktail party. Her elderly mother usually attends the affairs and enjoys herself, so the daughter invites her as usual — but this time, the mother declines. Naturally, the daughter worries. Is her mother ill? Depressed? This is not like her.
headline.main: Aging’s Misunderstood Virtues

abstract: This entertaining romp through the unconscious mind reads as vivid reportage overlaid with a sampling of science.
snippet: This entertaining romp through the unconscious mind reads as vivid reportage overlaid with a sampling of science.
lead_paragraph: Invisible forces that control our behavior have inspired our best story­tellers, from Euripides to Steven Spielberg. Whether we’re yanked around by jealous gods, Oedipal urges or poltergeists, the idea that we feel powerless to direct our own actions has a visceral appeal, one exploited by Shankar Vedantam in “The Hidden Brain,” his exploration of the unconscious mind.

abstract: The drug maker agreed to settle charges of improper marketing of Seroquel, an antipsychotic.
snippet: The drug maker agreed to settle charges of improper marketing of Seroquel, an antipsychotic.
lead_paragraph: AstraZeneca has completed a deal to pay $520 million to settle federal investigations into marketing practices for its blockbuster schizophrenia drug, Seroquel, the Attorney General, Eric Holder, said at a news conference Tuesday afternoon.

snippet: Surprising research turns up at forum sponsored by the National Transportation Safety Board.
lead_paragraph: “There are a lot of different pieces to this puzzle,” said Deborah Hersman, chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, which last week sponsored a two-day forum called “Safety, Mobility and Aging Drivers.”

abstract: The hallmark of a good nursing home is low turnover among the aides who work there.
snippet: The hallmark of a good nursing home is low turnover among the aides who work there.
lead_paragraph: While looking at nursing homes for my mother, I always asked the tour guides if I could talk to the nurses’ aides. This seemed to me a logical request. After all, these were the women — and they were all women — who would spend the most time with my mother, who would notice small changes that raised big questions, who would make her feel cared for. Or not.
headline.main: One Way to Judge a Nursing Home

abstract: New devices for the aging appear at this week’s Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. But how many of them are truly useful?
snippet: New devices for the aging appear at this week’s Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. But how many of them are truly useful?
lead_paragraph: When the vast Consumer Electronics Show, underway this week in Las Vegas, adds an exhibition called Silvers Summit, devoted to new products for the aging and their caregivers, brace yourselves. American tech companies, taking notice of the unmistakable demographic trends, have launched a surge.
headline.main: Old Age, New Gizmos

abstract: Home care aides feel the loss, too, when their clients die, but there is little support for those are who grieving.
snippet: Home care aides feel the loss, too, when their clients die, but there is little support for those are who grieving.
lead_paragraph: Sam Einhorn was a few months short of turning 101 when he died last year, followed a few months later by his wife Pat, who was 90. Their family mourned. But they weren’t the only ones.
headline.main: On Home Aides and Hidden Grief

abstract: The drug maker is said to have agreed to settle charges of improper marketing of Seroquel, an antipsychotic.
snippet: The drug maker is said to have agreed to settle charges of improper marketing of Seroquel, an antipsychotic.
lead_paragraph: AstraZeneca has completed a deal to pay $520 million to settle federal investigations into marketing practices for its blockbuster schizophrenia drug, Seroquel. The Justice Department plans a news conference on Wednesday to disclose details of the case, according to two people close to the negotiations who were not authorized to discuss it publicly.
headline.main: For $520 Million, AstraZeneca Will Settle Case Over Marketing of a Drug

lead_paragraph: Maria Petrik spreads brittle sheets of paper across a delicate Romanian lace tablecloth. Each page is covered with handwritten translations of words that she and her husband, Gyorgy, taught themselves after arriving in Queens two decades ago.

abstract: Crime novels by Walter Mosley, Stuart Neville, Joseph Wambaugh and William G. Tapply.
snippet: Crime novels by Walter Mosley, Stuart Neville, Joseph Wambaugh and William G. Tapply.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the weaknesses of their free-form plots, Walter Mosley’s crime novels are redeemed by the earthy vitality of his characters: an exuberant pageant of fast-talking rogues and unrepentant sinners, high-stepping women, sharp young blades and children wise beyond their years. Meanwhile, on the sidelines, are his philosophical old souls, shaking their heads and laughing at the parade of fools.

abstract: One last attempt to connect with an estranged mother.
snippet: One last attempt to connect with an estranged mother.
lead_paragraph: Last winter, after more than three decades of silence, I desperately wanted to see my mother before it was too late. Not to make amends, really. I wanted to see her once and not be afraid. I had been courting her in recent years, sending flowers, fruit and candy for her birthday and holidays, asking to visit. She acknowledged my gifts with terse handwritten notes. She sent back the designer jelly beans with the scrawl “I prefer dark chocolate.” In the past, she ignored me completely, or her response ended with “you stupid idiot.” We were making progress. Yet she still refused to see me.

abstract: The more hits to the head you take as a youth, the more likely you are to experience brain deficits in later life, according to experts at the Mayo Clinic concussion conference.
snippet: The more hits to the head you take as a youth, the more likely you are to experience brain deficits in later life, according to experts at the Mayo Clinic concussion conference.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Jim Johnson, a fit 48-year-old who played 13 years in the N.H.L. before retiring in 1998, admitted he was nervous as he listened to Ann McKee, address the Mayo Clinic concussion conference here on Tuesday morning. McKee is the Boston University researcher who has done groundbreaking work with the donated brains of former athletes.
headline.main: At the Mayo Clinic: The Ex-N.H.L. Player With 9 Concussions

abstract: For caregivers trying to negotiate the vacation season with elderly parents, there are more choices than ever before.
snippet: For caregivers trying to negotiate the vacation season with elderly parents, there are more choices than ever before.
lead_paragraph: It’s August, time for a vacation from everything stressful — work, commuting, heat, congestion. But what about caregiving? Do adult children of elderly parents deserve a break from them, too?
headline.main: On the Road With, or Without, Elderly Parents

abstract: Graphic books by Joyce Farmer, Rian Hughes, Darwyn Cooke and Vanessa Davis.
snippet: Graphic books by Joyce Farmer, Rian Hughes, Darwyn Cooke and Vanessa Davis.
lead_paragraph: Forty years ago, the pioneering cartoonists of the underground comix movement turned the topics polite society didn’t speak about — sex, drugs, neurosis — into the stuff of their confessional art. Now that they’re older, they have a few final taboos to address bluntly. One of those doing so is Joyce Farmer, who in the ’70s contributed to the feminist anthology Wimmen’s Comix and helped create a notorious series about women’s sexuality whose title can’t be reproduced here. She’s kept a fairly low profile since then, but her new book, SPECIAL EXITS (Fantagraphics, $26.99), is forceful, unsparing and equally concerned, in its way, with saying the unsayable.

abstract: Patients with terminal lung cancer who had palliative care with oncology treatment lived three months longer.
snippet: Patients with terminal lung cancer who had palliative care with oncology treatment lived three months longer.
lead_paragraph: In a study that sheds new light on the effects of end-of-life care, doctors have found that patients with terminal lung cancer who began receiving palliative care immediately upon diagnosis not only were happier, more mobile and in less pain as the end neared  but they also lived nearly three months longer.
headline.main: Palliative Care Extends Life, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Palliative Care Found to Extend Life of Cancer Patients

abstract: The two new co-chairmen of the N.F.L. committee on head injuries were rebuked by members of a House panel for sounding “like the same old N.F.L.”
snippet: The two new co-chairmen of the N.F.L. committee on head injuries were rebuked by members of a House panel for sounding “like the same old N.F.L.”
lead_paragraph: In what could have been a fresh start for the N.F.L.’s committee on head injuries, its two new co-chairmen, making their first official remarks on concussions before a House Judiciary Committee panel on Monday in Manhattan, were heatedly rebuked by lawmakers for sounding “like the same old N.F.L.”

abstract: Storme DeLarverie fought the police in the riot at the Stonewall Inn that started the gay pride movement.
snippet: Storme DeLarverie fought the police in the riot at the Stonewall Inn that started the gay pride movement.
lead_paragraph: At noon on Sunday, thousands of marchers filled Fifth Avenue for New York City’s annual gay pride parade. Nearly six miles away, on the sixth floor of a nursing home in Brooklyn, the frail, white-haired woman in beige pajamas and brown slippers in Room 609 sat motionless at the edge of her bed, staring out her window.

abstract: Beta amyloid, which was once thought to be a chief villain in Alzheimer’s, may be part of the brain’s normal defenses, researchers at Harvard suggested.
snippet: Beta amyloid, which was once thought to be a chief villain in Alzheimer’s, may be part of the brain’s normal defenses, researchers at Harvard suggested.
lead_paragraph: For years, a prevailing theory has been that one of the chief villains in Alzheimer’s disease has no real function other than as a waste product that the brain never properly disposed of.

abstract: Sizing up a book meant to make applicants laugh, and other intended to make parents think, and feel.
snippet: Sizing up a book meant to make applicants laugh, and other intended to make parents think, and feel.
lead_paragraph: The Choice has taken a close look at two recently published college admissions books, each with especially catchy titles. One, “Don’t Stalk the Admissions Officer,” is intended for applicants; the other, “I’m Going to College — Not You!” is for parents.
headline.main: Book Reviews: ‘Don’t Stalk the Admissions Officer’ and ‘I’m Going to College — Not You!’

abstract: The public will be able to see four works owned by Michael Crichton that Christie’s is to sell on behalf of his estate in New York at the evening auctions in May.
snippet: The public will be able to see four works owned by Michael Crichton that Christie’s is to sell on behalf of his estate in New York at the evening auctions in May.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a little-known art world fact: In addition to writing thrillers like “The Andromeda Strain” and “Jurassic Park,” creating television hits like “ER” and directing movies including “Coma,” Michael Crichton collected art, though he kept his purchases to himself.

abstract: For all the assertions about the importance of caring in medicine, doctors as a profession have been slow to recognize family members who care for patients at home.

lead_paragraph: The man was nearing 90, losing his sight and showing signs of early dementia. After examining his abdomen, I fumbled trying to help him get his shirt and pants back on. abstract: Money scandals and on-field violence in the college game are nothing new. In 1905, Teddy Roosevelt had to step in to help reform the game.
snippet: Money scandals and on-field violence in the college game are nothing new. In 1905, Teddy Roosevelt had to step in to help reform the game.
lead_paragraph: HEADLINES on the sports pages in recent years paint a picture of scandal and violence in football: college students playing for pay; recruiters doling out money under the table; professional agents trolling campuses from North Carolina to Southern California. And in both the N.C.A.A. and the N.F.L., crippling tackles cause head injuries bad enough to lead to dementia and suicide.

abstract: Sure, it’s nitpicking to complain about hyphens. But if the goal is perfection — and it is, however elusive — we have to get the little things right. abstract: Decisions about aggressive treatment at the end of life are far from clear-cut.

lead_paragraph: Aggressive treatment at the end of life  frantic CPR for a brain-dead accident victim, inserting a feeding tube in a dying Alzheimer’s patient  has become a staple of the health care debate. Critics argue that vast resources are squandered on care that is obviously futile.

abstract: The key to a collaborative Alzheimer’s project was an ambitious agreement to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately.
snippet: The key to a collaborative Alzheimer’s project was an ambitious agreement to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, a group of scientists and executives from the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, the drug and medical-imaging industries, universities and nonprofit groups joined in a project that experts say had no precedent: a collaborative effort to find the biological markers that show the progression of Alzheimer’s disease in the human brain.

abstract: Mr. Anderson won World Series championships with the Cincinnati Reds of the National League and the Detroit Tigers of the American League.
snippet: Mr. Anderson won World Series championships with the Cincinnati Reds of the National League and the Detroit Tigers of the American League.
lead_paragraph: Sparky Anderson, who managed Cincinnati’s powerful Big Red Machine to baseball dominance in the 1970s and became the first manager to win World Series championships in both the National and American Leagues, died on Thursday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 76.

abstract: An Encores! concert version of “Anyone Can Whistle,” the composer’s biggest flop, hints at the greatness that followed.
snippet: An Encores! concert version of “Anyone Can Whistle,” the composer’s biggest flop, hints at the greatness that followed.
lead_paragraph: It’s not as if New York hasn’t known its share of power-addicted, egomaniac mayors. But there’s something special about Cora Hoover Hooper, the impeccably coiffed basket case who runs the broken-down little town in “Anyone Can Whistle,” Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurents’s muddled musical from 1964, which is stylishly exploring its own identity crisis at City Center this weekend.

abstract: Last week, a reader noticed a small but annoying usage error in an online article: the misuse of the contraction “it’s” for the possessive “its,” a staple of fourth-grade English essays. This reader cared enough to alert us via e-mail, and editors here made the fix online. When I (gently) chastised some colleagues for letting this slip through, we found out that the error had actually been fixed in the original editing process. But because of an arcane technical glitch, an earlier, partially edited version of the story was initially posted online. Our copy editors were blameless; our technical experts went to work to fix the glitch. But the little episode had several lessons.
snippet: Last week, a reader noticed a small but annoying usage error in an online article: the misuse of the contraction “it’s” for the possessive “its,” a staple of fourth-grade English essays. This reader cared enough to alert us via e-mail, and editors...
lead_paragraph: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.
headline.main: The Little Things

abstract: Dangerously low blood pressure and a strange rash. Could they be related?
snippet: Dangerously low blood pressure and a strange rash. Could they be related?
lead_paragraph: “I feel a swimming in my head,” mumbled the voice on the phone. Dr. Stephanie Pouch, a resident in her second year of training, wasn’t sure what to make of this elderly gentleman’s strange complaint. Was he feeling dizzy? He wasn’t sure; all he could say was that his head was “swimming” and that he almost passed out. Uncertain of the cause or even the nature of the complaint, Pouch sent the man to the emergency room. She was on call that day at the University of Chicago Medical Center. She would figure it out when he got there.

abstract: Last week, a reader noticed a small but annoying usage error in an online article: the misuse of the contraction “it’s” for the possessive “its,” a staple of fourth-grade English essays. This reader cared enough to alert us via e-mail, and editors here made the fix online. When I (gently) chastised some colleagues for letting this slip through, we found out that the error had actually been fixed in the original editing process. But because of an arcane technical glitch, an earlier, partially edited version of the story was initially posted online. Our copy editors were blameless; our technical experts went to work to fix the glitch. But the little episode had several lessons.

abstract: The story of the unexpected selection of John Roberts as chief justice five years ago demonstrates how arbitrary and contingent history can be.
snippet: The story of the unexpected selection of John Roberts as chief justice five years ago demonstrates how arbitrary and contingent history can be.
lead_paragraph: The Pew Research Center asked people this summer to identify the current chief justice of the United States from among four possibilities: John Roberts, Thurgood Marshall, John Paul Stevens and Harry Reid. Only 28 percent correctly picked Chief Justice Roberts. The late Thurgood Marshall came in second, with 8 percent. Fifty-three percent could not make a selection, answering “don’t know.”

abstract: As members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 65, they may need to re-examine the notion that “age is just a number.”
snippet: As members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 65, they may need to re-examine the notion that “age is just a number.”
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY turned 65, just ahead of the millions in the baby boom generation who will begin to cross the same symbolically fraught threshold in the new year to a chorus of well-intended assurances that “age is just a number.” But my family album tells a different story. I am descended from a long line of women who lived into their 90s, and their last years suggest that my generation’s vision of an ageless old age bears about as much resemblance to real old age as our earlier idealization of painless childbirth without drugs did to real labor.
headline.main: Real Life Among the Old Old
headline.print_headline: Real Life Among the Old Old

abstract: The jazz pianist Fred Hersch has overcome AIDS-related dementia, a two-month coma and the loss of motor function in his hands. Now he’s trying to capture the experience in music.
snippet: The jazz pianist Fred Hersch has overcome AIDS-related dementia, a two-month coma and the loss of motor function in his hands. Now he’s trying to capture the experience in music.
lead_paragraph: Influential artists sometimes click in the public consciousness only after the rise of the movements they have influenced. A school of creative work emerges — seemingly spontaneously, its origins obscure at first. Then, with attention to the artists in that school comes recognition of their influences, their antecedents and their mentors. After Pollock, de Kooning and their peers in postwar American art established Abstract Expressionism, the precursory importance of prewar iconoclasts like Kandinsky became clear. After the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and the Clash blurted forth punk rock in the 1970s, a rude vision became apparent in the noise of ’60s garage bands like the Seeds.

abstract: Buying your parents’ house can seem like a good idea, but Mom and Dad may not like what you’ve done with the place.
snippet: Buying your parents’ house can seem like a good idea, but Mom and Dad may not like what you’ve done with the place.
lead_paragraph: IN the annals of intergenerational friction, there are some familiar sources of disagreement: sex, money, music and what on earth you’re going to do with your life. Then there are the truly contentious subjects — like the fireplace tiles that used to be in Carla Weisberg’s apartment on West 12th Street in Greenwich Village.

abstract: Some conservatives think intransigence is a political winner. One who disagreed, David Frum, got fired.
snippet: Some conservatives think intransigence is a political winner. One who disagreed, David Frum, got fired.
lead_paragraph: Well, Karl Rove isn’t one to let a downpour dampen his parade. “Democrats are celebrating victory,” the Republican strategist wrote in The Wall Street Journal after President Obama signed the health care reform package. “The public outcry against what they’ve done doesn’t seem to bother them. They take it as validation that they are succeeding at transforming America. But we’ve seen this movie before and it won’t end happily for Democrats.”
headline.main: Can ‘No’ Revive the Republicans?

abstract: Antipsychotic drugs are the top-selling pharmaceuticals in America. But with the surge in use has come an increase in questions — and lawsuits — about aggressive marketing and the scientific soundness of drug companies’ studies.
snippet: Antipsychotic drugs are the top-selling pharmaceuticals in America. But with the surge in use has come an increase in questions — and lawsuits — about aggressive marketing and the scientific soundness of drug companies’ studies.
lead_paragraph: FOR decades, antipsychotic drugs were a niche product. Today, they’re the top-selling class of pharmaceuticals in America, generating annual revenue of about $14.6 billion and surpassing sales of even blockbusters like heart-protective statins.

abstract: New science is showing that estrogen’s effects on women’s minds and bodies may depend upon when they first start taking it. What should you do?
snippet: New science is showing that estrogen’s effects on women’s minds and bodies may depend upon when they first start taking it. What should you do?
lead_paragraph: Here we are, two fast-talking women on estrogen, staring at a wall of live mitochondria from the brain of a rat. Mitochondria are cellular energy generators of unfathomably tiny size, but these are vivid and big because they were hit with dye in a petri dish and enlarged for projection purposes. They’re winking and zooming, like shooting stars. “Oh, my God,” Roberta Diaz Brinton said. “Look at that one. I love these. I love shooting mitochondria.”

abstract: What the research shows about the relationship between relationships and physical well-being.
snippet: What the research shows about the relationship between relationships and physical well-being.
lead_paragraph: In 1858, a British epidemiologist named William Farr set out to study what he called the “conjugal condition” of the people of France. He divided the adult population into three distinct categories: the “married,” consisting of husbands and wives; the “celibate,” defined as the bachelors and spinsters who had never married; and finally the “widowed,” those who had experienced the death of a spouse. Using birth, death and marriage records, Farr analyzed the relative mortality rates of the three groups at various ages. The work, a groundbreaking study that helped establish the field of medical statistics, showed that the unmarried died from disease “in undue proportion” to their married counterparts. And the widowed, Farr found, fared worst of all.

abstract: Can Lt. Col. Guy Jones win the battle to build responsible self-government?
snippet: Can Lt. Col. Guy Jones win the battle to build responsible self-government?
lead_paragraph: Lt. Col. Guy Jones, commander of the 82nd Airborne Division’s Second Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry, is on his fourth tour of Afghanistan. The first time around, in June 2002, when he was a 31-year-old company commander, his job was to find Osama bin Laden. He still has happy memories of working alongside Gul Agha Shirzai, the local strongman in Kandahar, who may have been loathed by the people but could be counted on to deliver American war materiel to anywhere in the region for only $5,000 a truckload.

abstract: New York Times reporters and editors provide live analysis from Miami of Super Bowl XLIV between the Colts and Saints.
snippet: New York Times reporters and editors provide live analysis from Miami of Super Bowl XLIV between the Colts and Saints.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors, including Judy Battista, Greg Bishop, Tom Jolly and Justin Sablich, provided live analysis from Miami Gardens, Fla., of Super Bowl XLIV between the Colts and the Saints. Richard Sandomir, contributing from New York, added commentary on the CBS telecast. The Media Decoder blog commented on the Super Bowl ads here.

abstract: The U.S. Army's modified exercise programs, which focus more on the recruits' expanding girth, could inform a broader public health issue.
snippet: The U.S. Army's modified exercise programs, which focus more on the recruits' expanding girth, could inform a broader public health issue.
lead_paragraph: Regarding the article “Getting soldiers in shape for war: Situps are out, yoga is in” (Sept. 1): The U.S. Army’s modified exercise programs, which focus more on the recruits’ expanding girth, could inform a broader public health issue. Waistlines, not body weight alone, are a more reliable indicator for a host of diseases, including cardiovascular disease, Type 2 diabetes, asthma, cancer, even dementia and Alzheimer’s. The average 19-year-old male in the United States has a 35-inch waistline — a limit that the recently trapped miners in Chile must face due to the limitations of the escape tunnel in progress, a compelling reminder that our girth and survival are linked.
headline.main: Watching Those Waistlines
headline.kicker: Letters to the International Herald Tribune
headline.print_headline: Watching Those Waistlines
